title: How to Add Flavor to a Bland Recipe

steps.headline: Use house seasoning.
steps.description: Otherwise known as salt and pepper, adding a dash of this simple seasoning will improve many dishes. Add a small amount and taste as you go. Freshly ground salt and pepper will taste fresher and sharper than already ground versions.

steps.headline: Add a dash of a prepared seasoning.
steps.description: There are many varieties of prepared seasoning that can be purchased. Some are generic and suit a range of savory dishes, while others are targeted to particular foods. Follow the instructions accompanying the seasoning.

steps.headline: Make and use your own general seasoning.
steps.description:
Seasoning mixes aren't hard to make at home in large batches for use over several months. You can be absolutely sure about what the mix contains, making this an even better option. Examples include:
Seasoned salt
Seasoned pepper
Chicken and rice seasoning mix
Taco seasoning mix

Italian herb seasoning.

steps.headline: Try lemon juice.
steps.description: Lemon juice is said to be a healthier alternative for salt. It has a tangy flavor and enhances flavors like no other. Add 2 tablespoons to a salad dressing or fish dish.

steps.headline: Try lime juice.
steps.description: This has a milder but more distinct taste than a lemon. The bitterness can give a dish that bite it needs. Add 2 tablespoons.

steps.headline: Use hot sauce.
steps.description: The all time favorite. It gives food a spicy, tangy flavor. It can be added to literally any dish! Add as much as you'd like.

steps.headline: Use spices to improve the flavor of both savory and sweet dishes.
steps.description: There are many possibilities for improving food with spice. Start by checking out How to use spices in cookery.

steps.headline: Use spices with a bit of kick to improve chill and other dishes that need a hot kick.
steps.description: For example, cayenne, paprika, strong black pepper, etc.

steps.headline: Improve the flavor of a bland sweet pie with spices.
steps.description: It's already too late to fix the pie but you can add pumpkin pie spice or similar to the whipped cream or sauce that goes with the pie. Or, add sweet spices to powdered sugar and sprinkle over every slice of pie.

steps.headline: Prefer fresh herbs over dried herbs where possible.
steps.description: On the whole, fresh herbs have a better flavor and will add great taste to help remove blandness from food. Consider growing a kitchen herb garden of your most-used herbs to make it easy to add the herbs to any dish as needed.

steps.headline: Use celery salt or celery seed.
steps.description: This has a strong flavor which is good for improving a bland soup or stew.

steps.headline: Add a decent dash of soy sauce.
steps.description: The saltiness and flavor of soy sauce will improve a bland soup, stew, stir-fry and other savory dishes that have a a liquid component.

steps.headline: Add ketchup or tomato sauce.
steps.description: The acidic flavor adds one dimension, while any additional flavorings in the sauce will add depth to the dish too.

steps.headline: Pour in a little Worcestershire sauce.
steps.description: This is a strongly-flavored sauce, so don't overdo it or you'll be looking for how to tone down the flavor. Add a dash or two to soups, stews and similar savory dishes.

steps.headline: Use sherry.
steps.description: It can be either drinking sherry or cooking sherry; whichever, it will add flavor to bland soups, casseroles, stews, chilli, etc.

steps.headline: Add white wine.
steps.description: White wine can add acidity and sweetness to a bland dish. It's a good way to use up the last of a bottle. Dry vermouth can also add flavor in the same way as white wine.

text:
Seasoning Use house seasoning. Otherwise known as salt and pepper, adding a dash of this simple seasoning will improve many dishes. Add a small amount and taste as you go. Freshly ground salt and pepper will taste fresher and sharper than already ground versions. Add a dash of a prepared seasoning. There are many varieties of prepared seasoning that can be purchased. Some are generic and suit a range of savory dishes, while others are targeted to particular foods. Follow the instructions accompanying the seasoning. Make and use your own general seasoning. Seasoning mixes aren't hard to make at home in large batches for use over several months. You can be absolutely sure about what the mix contains, making this an even better option. Examples include:
Seasoned salt
Seasoned pepper
Chicken and rice seasoning mix
Taco seasoning mix

Italian herb seasoning. Citrus Try lemon juice. Lemon juice is said to be a healthier alternative for salt. It has a tangy flavor and enhances flavors like no other. Add 2 tablespoons to a salad dressing or fish dish. Try lime juice. This has a milder but more distinct taste than a lemon. The bitterness can give a dish that bite it needs. Add 2 tablespoons. Spice Use hot sauce. The all time favorite. It gives food a spicy, tangy flavor. It can be added to literally any dish! Add as much as you'd like. Use spices to improve the flavor of both savory and sweet dishes. There are many possibilities for improving food with spice. Start by checking out How to use spices in cookery. Use spices with a bit of kick to improve chill and other dishes that need a hot kick. For example, cayenne, paprika, strong black pepper, etc. Improve the flavor of a bland sweet pie with spices. It's already too late to fix the pie but you can add pumpkin pie spice or similar to the whipped cream or sauce that goes with the pie. Or, add sweet spices to powdered sugar and sprinkle over every slice of pie. Herbs Prefer fresh herbs over dried herbs where possible. On the whole, fresh herbs have a better flavor and will add great taste to help remove blandness from food. Consider growing a kitchen herb garden of your most-used herbs to make it easy to add the herbs to any dish as needed. Use celery salt or celery seed. This has a strong flavor which is good for improving a bland soup or stew. Sauces Add a decent dash of soy sauce. The saltiness and flavor of soy sauce will improve a bland soup, stew, stir-fry and other savory dishes that have a a liquid component. Add ketchup or tomato sauce. The acidic flavor adds one dimension, while any additional flavorings in the sauce will add depth to the dish too. Pour in a little Worcestershire sauce. This is a strongly-flavored sauce, so don't overdo it or you'll be looking for how to tone down the flavor. Add a dash or two to soups, stews and similar savory dishes. Alcohol Use sherry. It can be either drinking sherry or cooking sherry; whichever, it will add flavor to bland soups, casseroles, stews, chilli, etc. Add white wine. White wine can add acidity and sweetness to a bland dish. It's a good way to use up the last of a bottle. Dry vermouth can also add flavor in the same way as white wine.
sentences: Seasoning Use house seasoning.
Otherwise known as salt and pepper, adding a dash of this simple seasoning will improve many dishes.
Add a small amount and taste as you go.
Freshly ground salt and pepper will taste fresher and sharper than already ground versions.
Add a dash of a prepared seasoning.
There are many varieties of prepared seasoning that can be purchased.
Some are generic and suit a range of savory dishes, while others are targeted to particular foods.
Follow the instructions accompanying the seasoning.
Make and use your own general seasoning.
Seasoning mixes aren't hard to make at home in large batches for use over several months.
You can be absolutely sure about what the mix contains, making this an even better option.

Examples include:
Seasoned salt
Seasoned pepper
Chicken and rice seasoning mix
Taco seasoning mix

Italian herb seasoning.
Citrus Try lemon juice.
Lemon juice is said to be a healthier alternative for salt.
It has a tangy flavor and enhances flavors like no other.
Add 2 tablespoons to a salad dressing or fish dish.
Try lime juice.
This has a milder but more distinct taste than a lemon.
The bitterness can give a dish that bite it needs.
Add 2 tablespoons.
Spice Use hot sauce.
The all time favorite.
It gives food a spicy, tangy flavor.
It can be added to literally any dish!
Add as much as you'd like.
Use spices to improve the flavor of both savory and sweet dishes.
There are many possibilities for improving food with spice.
Start by checking out How to use spices in cookery.
Use spices with a bit of kick to improve chill and other dishes that need a hot kick.
For example, cayenne, paprika, strong black pepper, etc.
Improve the flavor of a bland sweet pie with spices.
It's already too late to fix the pie but you can add pumpkin pie spice or similar to the whipped cream or sauce that goes with the pie.
Or, add sweet spices to powdered sugar and sprinkle over every slice of pie.
Herbs Prefer fresh herbs over dried herbs where possible.
On the whole, fresh herbs have a better flavor and will add great taste to help remove blandness from food.
Consider growing a kitchen herb garden of your most-used herbs to make it easy to add the herbs to any dish as needed.
Use celery salt or celery seed.
This has a strong flavor which is good for improving a bland soup or stew.
Sauces Add a decent dash of soy sauce.
The saltiness and flavor of soy sauce will improve a bland soup, stew, stir-fry and other savory dishes that have a a liquid component.
Add ketchup or tomato sauce.
The acidic flavor adds one dimension, while any additional flavorings in the sauce will add depth to the dish too.
Pour in a little Worcestershire sauce.
This is a strongly-flavored sauce, so don't overdo it or you'll be looking for how to tone down the flavor.
Add a dash or two to soups, stews and similar savory dishes.
Alcohol Use sherry.
It can be either drinking sherry or cooking sherry; whichever, it will add flavor to bland soups, casseroles, stews, chilli, etc.
Add white wine.
White wine can add acidity and sweetness to a bland dish.
It's a good way to use up the last of a bottle.
Dry vermouth can also add flavor in the same way as white wine.
